excerpt: Town square with bars & eateries next to the namesake observation platform popular with tourists.
detail_description: Pl. Balcón de Europa is a bustling town square in Nerja, offering stunning views of the coast, including Calahonda and Burriana beaches, neighboring coves, and the village of Maro. It was built on a 17th-century fortress with historical significance dating back to the 9th century. King Alfonso XII named it as the 'Balcony of Europe,' claiming it to be the best view on the continent.
name: Pl. Balcón de Europa

excerpt: Expansive cave complex viewed by guided tour, also hosting a classical music & dance festival.
detail_description: Fundación Cueva de Nerja is an expansive cave complex located 4km east of Nerja, offering guided tours through a surreal world of extraordinary rock formations, subtle shifting colors, and impressive stalactites and stalagmites. Discovered in 1959 by local young men looking for bats, the caves date back around five million years and were once inhabited by Stone Age hunters. The site also holds historical significance as it was repopulated under Christian rule to prevent further population decline.
name: Fundación Cueva de Nerja
address: Carr. de Bajada a Playa de Maro, 29787, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Frigiliana is a town in southern Spain. It's known for its Moorish old quarter and narrow streets decorated with ceramic mosaics. El Ingenio is a 16th-century Renaissance palace now housing a sugar cane factory. Exhibits at the Archaeological Museum include Neolithic bones, Phoenician pottery and a 16th-century dagger. Sierras de Tejeda, Almijara y Alhama Natural Park shelters Spanish ibex and peregrine falcons.
detail_description: Frigiliana, a picturesque town in southern Spain, is famous for its Moorish old quarter and narrow streets adorned with ceramic mosaics. The 16th-century Renaissance palace, El Ingenio, now houses a sugar cane factory and the Archaeological Museum showcases Neolithic bones, Phoenician pottery, and a 16th-century dagger. The village is divided into an old original part and a newer section.
name: Frigiliana

detail_description: Nerja, located on the Malaga coast in the Axarquia region, is known for its local products such as Axarca made in Frigliana and craft beer from La Domadura y Leon. These unique offerings provide visitors with a taste of the area's distinct flavors and artisanal creations.
name: Nerja

excerpt: Small, pebbly beach situated between rocky cliffs, with lounge chairs & umbrellas available.
detail_description: Playa de la Calahonda is a small, pebbly beach nestled between rocky cliffs, making it one of the most famous and iconic beaches in Nerja. Located next to Balcon de Europa, this 120-meter beach offers stunning views and easy accessibility from the town center. While it can get crowded due to its central location, visitors can explore nearby swimming caves like Playa El Chorrillo for a quieter experience.
name: Playa de la Calahonda

excerpt: Interactive museum exploring the history of Nerja from Paleolitic times to the 20th century.
detail_description: The Museum of the village of Nerja, situated in the heart of Nerja's historical center near Balcon de Europa, offers an immersive journey through the history of the area from Paleolithic times to the 20th century. The exhibits showcase a diverse range of cultures that have influenced Nerja, including the Phoenicians and Moors. Visitors can explore themed areas detailing the origins and resources of the settlement, as well as learn about significant discoveries such as the Nerja caves.
name: Museum of the village of Nerja
address: Plaza de España, 4, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Maro is a charming coastal town nestled in the heart of the Costa del Sol, known for its stunning beaches, vibrant nightlife, and rich cultural heritage. The town boasts beautiful white-washed buildings, narrow cobblestone streets, and a lively atmosphere that attracts visitors from all over the world. Maro is also famous for its crystal-clear waters and pristine beaches, making it a paradise for sunbathers and water sports enthusiasts.
name: Maro

excerpt: Relaxed, simple sandy beach lined with palm trees, an option for swimming & sunbathing.
detail_description: El Salón beach in Nerja, Spain is a relaxed and simple sandy beach with palm trees, perfect for swimming and sunbathing. It stretches over 200 meters along the Mediterranean Sea, offering a tranquil atmosphere away from the crowds. The access road may be challenging to find, making it a quiet place to enjoy the crashing waves. The beach provides standard amenities such as lifeguards, showers, and nearby restaurants and bars.
name: El Salón beach

excerpt: Built in the 19th century, this aqueduct features 4 levels of superimposed arches.
detail_description: Nestled just a few kilometers east of Nerja, the Aqueduct Eagle, or Acueducto del Águila, is a stunning example of 19th-century Mudejar architecture. This impressive structure boasts four levels of red-brick arches—37 in total—that elegantly span the Barranco de la Coladilla ravine. Originally built to transport water to the now-defunct San Joaquin de Maro sugar refinery, it continues to serve local farmers for irrigation today.
name: Aqueduct Eagle
address: Barranco de la Coladilla, s/n, 29787 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Large sandy beach offering swimming & sunbathing, plus numerous nearby eateries.
detail_description: Playa de Burriana is the largest and most popular beach in the area, located just a 15-minute walk from the town center. During summer, this Blue Flag beach offers a wide range of activities such as water sports, seafront promenades, and play areas for children. It's known for its fine golden sand and has been featured on TV shows. Visitors can enjoy various water sports like jet skiing and sea kayaking or simply relax on sunbeds available for hire.
name: Playa de Burriana

excerpt: Energetic beach offering boat rentals, kiosks & lifeguards, plus a promenade with eateries & shops.
detail_description: Playa Burriana is a lively beach located in Nerja, offering a range of activities and amenities. It's known for its energetic atmosphere, with options for boat rentals, kiosks, and lifeguards available. The beach is lined with restaurants, tapas bars, and shops, making it a popular destination for visitors. Playa Burriana also features smooth sand and gentle surf, making it ideal for families and kids.
name: Playa Burriana
address: Cam. de Burriana, s/n, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Nerja is a resort town along southern Spain's Costa del Sol. Its seafront promenade, Balcón de Europa, tops a promontory with views of the Mediterranean and surrounding mountains. Below it lie sandy beaches and cliffside coves. Cueva de Nerja, a nearby cavern with unusual stalactites and stalagmites, hosts popular summertime concerts. It's also known for its paleolithic paintings, viewable by guided tour.
detail_description: Nerja, a charming resort town located along the Costa del Sol in southern Spain, offers stunning views of the Mediterranean and surrounding mountains from its seafront promenade, Balcón de Europa. The town boasts sandy beaches, cliffside coves, and the nearby Cueva de Nerja, a cavern with unique stalactites and stalagmites that hosts popular summertime concerts. Visitors can also explore paleolithic paintings on guided tours.
name: Nerja

excerpt: Seaside cliffs for tranquil walks & picturesque views of adjacent mountains, beaches & coves.
detail_description: The Cliffs of Maro-Cerro Gordo, located between Axarquia and Costa del Sol in Nerja, offer tranquil walks with picturesque views of mountains, beaches, and coves. This nature reserve spans 14 kilometers and features hidden coves beneath cliffs, creating a unique natural environment with small pebble beaches. The area is home to rich biodiversity including rock formations, caves, posidonia beds, sponges, corals, molluscs, and various fish species.
name: Cliffs of Maro-Cerro Gordo

excerpt: Life-size replica of a fishing boat featured in the hit 1980s Spanish TV series “Verano Azul”.
detail_description: If you're wandering through the charming town of Nerja, a must-see attraction is the Barco de Chanquete 'La Dorada,' a life-size replica of the iconic fishing boat from the beloved 1980s Spanish TV series 'Verano Azul.' This nostalgic piece of television history draws fans from around the globe, allowing visitors to relive cherished memories associated with the show.
name: Barco de chanquete La Dorada
address: C. Antonio Ferrandis Chanquete, s/n, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Sharing platters of regional seafood paella & baked fideuà noodles beside the Mediterranean.
detail_description: Walking into Ayo Nerja, you are transported to a warm and inviting Mediterranean restaurant. The intimate setting allows for a more personal dining experience, with the option to eat right on the beachfront. The extensive menu offers a variety of regional seafood dishes as well as baked fideuà noodles. From paellas cooked over an open flame to more flavourful options, there is something for everyone at this popular Nerja restaurant.
name: Ayo

detail_description: When exploring the charming old town, make sure to include Plaza de España in your itinerary. This expansive square is a popular venue for various events and markets, and it also houses the Nerja History Museum. For convenient parking in the area, consider using the reasonably priced underground parking facility situated directly beneath Plaza de España.
name: Plaza de España

excerpt: Remote sandy cove popular with snorkelers, featuring clear water & a restaurant/bar.
detail_description: Cala del Cañuelo is a remote sandy cove located to the east of Maro, offering clear waters and a great spot for snorkeling. This picturesque area boasts dramatic cliffs, lovely coves, and azure waters, making it an excellent destination for nature-loving beachgoers. While there are limited amenities available, visitors can find little restaurants along the roadside. The beach is known for its beautiful natural surroundings and a restaurant serving delicious seafood dishes at reasonable prices.
name: Cala del Cañuelo

detail_description: Parroquia El Salvador, located in Nerja, is a serene and sacred venue ideal for couples seeking a meaningful and spiritual union. The church offers Mass in both English and Spanish, creating a prayerful atmosphere filled with wonderful singing. Built in the Baroque and Rococo style, the church features ornate decorations and a golden color scheme dominating the statues and altar area.
name: Iglesia El Salvador
address: Pl. de Cavana, 13, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: The cultural center, Centro Cultural Villa de Nerja, is located in an excellent area and boasts a unique building design. Visitors are pleasantly surprised by the elevator access to the upper floors. The venue offers comfortable seating arrangements for a variety of cultural events that should not be missed. There is a diverse range of artists and performances available, including some free events. The theater is conveniently situated near wonderful dining and nightlife options while offering friendly staff to assist with your experience.
name: Centro Cultural Villa de Nerja

excerpt: Picturesque overlook offering panoramic views of the sea, beaches & distant mountains.
detail_description: Balcón de Europa is a stunning overlook located in Nerja, offering breathtaking panoramic views of the Mediterranean Sea, nearby beaches, and distant mountains. Situated on a rocky cliff facing the sea, this picturesque area features typical Andalusian coastal town architecture with whitewashed houses adorned with flowers and narrow pedestrian streets leading to terraces with impressive coastline vistas.
name: Balcón de Europa
address: Pl. Balcón de Europa, 5, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Tapas snacks in a convivial setting with a circular bar, plus outdoor seating around wine barrels.
detail_description: Bar Redondo is Nerja's most popular bar for tapas, with a relaxed and convivial atmosphere. It features a circular bar, plus outdoor seating around wine barrels. The menu includes a variety of tapas to accompany a drink, and the atmosphere is perfect for summer evenings.
name: Bar Redondo
address: C. de la Gloria, 10, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Fried fish specialties dished up in a bar & restaurant that has a laid-back atmosphere & a terrace.
detail_description: Bar El Pulguilla is a popular spot in Nerja known for its laid-back atmosphere and delicious fried fish specialties. Situated in a central street near the Balcony of Europe, it offers stunning views from its terrace. The bar is famous for its seafood tapas and fresh roast pepper salads. It's a favorite among locals, serving up some of the best tapas in Nerja.
name: Bar El Pulguilla
address: C. Almte. Ferrándiz, 26, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Pico del Cielo is a popular hiking destination known for its breathtaking views and challenging ascent. The trail, starting near Nerja Caves, offers diverse landscapes including pine forests and rocky cliffs before reaching one of the highest peaks in the area. Along the way, hikers can enjoy panoramic vistas of the Mediterranean coastline, Nerja, and distant mountains. The route also features historical landmarks such as the ruins of San Joaquin sugar mill.
name: Pico del Cielo

excerpt: Rustic, clear-water pebble beach surrounded by cliffs, at the site of a former paper mill.
detail_description: Playa del Molino de Papel is a secluded and rustic pebble beach located near the village of Maro, east of Nerja. Surrounded by cliffs and lush vegetation, this hidden gem offers a pristine and untouched environment within the Maro-Cerro Gordo Natural Park. Accessible via a detour from N-340, it provides a more private beach experience with crystal clear waters and an old paper mill nearby.
name: Playa del Molino de Papel

detail_description: Playa la Caletilla is a hidden gem located just below the iconic Balcon de Europa in Nerja, a charming coastal town on the Malaga province. This picturesque beach offers stunning views of flower-adorned cliffs and the sparkling blue sea, making it an ideal spot for families with young children. The journey to this lovely cove involves wandering through narrow streets lined with pristine white walls that evoke a Santorini vibe.
name: Playa la Caletilla
Fuente de Europa
address: Avenida, Calle Castilla Pérez, 21C, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: This small, coarse-sand beach is surrounded by grassy hills & offers kayaking, snorkeling & diving.
detail_description: Playa de Maro is a hidden gem along the stunning Andalusian coastline, just a stone's throw from the quaint fishing village that shares its name. This small beach, characterized by its coarse sand and surrounded by lush grassy hills, offers an idyllic setting for sunbathers and adventure seekers alike. The dramatic rock formations framing the cove create a picturesque backdrop, while the nearby Maro waterfall adds to its natural allure.
name: Playa de Maro

excerpt: Popular sandy beach close to eateries & bars features a  promenade & Moorish tower ruins.
detail_description: Playa Torrecilla is a popular sandy beach in Nerja, known for its proximity to eateries and bars. It features a promenade and the ruins of a Moorish tower. While it may not be the prettiest beach in Nerja, it is conveniently located near Hotel Riu Monica. The beach stretches about 300 meters and consists of coarse dark sand and pebbles.
name: Playa Torrecilla

excerpt: Themed after the '80s TV series "Blue Summer," this park with a ship replica is a place for leisure.
detail_description: Parque Verano Azul is a leisure park in Nerja, inspired by the famous '80s TV series "Blue Summer." The area is family-friendly and offers daytime and nighttime entertainment. Visitors can explore historical sites such as the caves of Nerja, which are well-preserved prehistoric monuments. Additionally, tourists have the opportunity to take a tour with Tito, one of the actors from the Verano Azul series.
name: Parque Verano Azul
address: C. Antonio Ferrandis Chanquete, 15, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

excerpt: Rugged, mountainous national park featuring hiking & climbing, plus waterfalls & sweeping views.
detail_description: The Parque Natural de Sierras de Tejeda, Almijara y Alhama is a rugged and mountainous national park that offers a range of outdoor activities. It surrounds the city of Nerja, providing a stunning backdrop of limestone mountain ranges overlooking the Mediterranean. The park features various hiking trails, waterfalls, and natural wonders to explore.
name: Parque Natural de Sierras de Tejeda, Almijara y Alhama
address: Urb. Costa Aguilera Alta, 115, 18680 Salobreña, Granada, Spain

name: Mirador del Bendito
address: C. Hernando de Carabeo, 107, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Tetería Zaidín, located in the historic center of Nerja, offers a serene and laid-back setting for a delightful evening with loved ones. The Arabic-style building and the charming Andalusian patio adorned with lush greenery provide an inviting atmosphere. The teahouse boasts an extensive menu featuring cocktails, teas, coffees, milkshakes, Arab sweets, cakes, and crepes.
name: Tetería Zaidín

detail_description: Playa Carabeillo is a charming and secluded beach in Nerja, located near Burriana Beach. It is surrounded by cliffs and offers a less crowded alternative to its neighboring beach. The area is still frequented by local fishermen, adding to the authentic atmosphere of the place. Visitors can enjoy the clear waters and fine golden sand, as well as lush vegetation that surrounds the area.
name: Playa Carabeillo
address: C. Hernando de Carabeo, 84, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Playa El Chorrillo, located in the province of Malaga, is a popular destination for both local and foreign tourists. It is particularly favored by visitors from European countries such as Italy, England, Germany, and France. The beach is known for its large size and its connection to Molino de Papel Beach via the remains of Torre del Rio de la Miel. Accessible through a detour from N-340, it offers a pleasant setting for a typical beach day.
name: Playa El Chorrillo
address: C. Hernando de Carabeo, 26, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Plaza Tutti Frutti, also known as Nerja's top nightlife spot, is a compact plaza filled with club bars that come alive on warm weekends. Located away from the touristy Centro Historico but just a short walk from Balcon de Europa, this hub for nighttime entertainment offers a mix of cocktail bars and clubs. With some venues staying open until 4:00 am, it's the perfect place to continue the evening after dinner.
name: Plaza Tutti Frutti

detail_description: El Cielo, also known as "Heaven," is the highest mountain in the region, standing at 1,500 meters above sea level. There are various accessible routes to reach its summit, offering stunning views of the Andalusian Coast and Costa del Sol. The trek begins near Nerja Caves and spans approximately 20km round-trip. While it's not a simple stroll, the journey is worth it for the legendary panoramic vistas from the peak.
name: Cruz del Cielo

detail_description: Los Cahorros del Rio Chillar is a hidden gem nestled within the stunning landscapes of Malaga province. This enchanting route begins amidst towering eucalyptus trees and leads you through the riverbed, where nature reveals its secrets. As you venture along this 8-kilometer trail, you'll encounter breathtaking narrow ravines adorned with waterfalls and inviting swimming holes, making it an ideal family-friendly hike. The path is mostly flat, allowing for easy exploration with kids of all ages.
name: Los Cahorros del Rio Chillar

detail_description: Torre de Maro is a must-see destination with various activities to enjoy. The route offers an exploration of the old sugar mill and the striking aqueduct, El Puente de Aguila. It leads up to the tower, offering outstanding views of the coast. The area features secluded beaches like La Caleta de Maro and busy beaches with water sports like Burriana Beach.
name: Torre de Maro
address: Carr. de Almería, 29787 Maro, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: La Ermita de Nuestra Señora de las Angustias, also known as the Chapel of Lady of Anguish, is a historic site in Nerja. Built in 1720 by the Lopez de Alcantara family, it was later handed over to the village and the Cathedral of Malaga due to financial constraints. This small Baroque-style chapel features elegant paintings and murals, offering an intimate setting for visitors.
name: Ermita de Nuestra Señora de las Angustias
address: Pl. de la Ermita, 11, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Mirador de la Torrecilla is a must-visit spot in Nerja for a day trip. It offers stunning views of Playa Torrecilla and features the ruins of Atalaya de la Torrecilla, an ancient watchtower. The area is popular among water sports enthusiasts, offering opportunities for rowing and surfskiing. While the fortifications are somewhat rundown, the viewpoint provides a chance to spot dolphins swimming along the coast.
name: Mirador de la Torrecilla

detail_description: Puente del Águila is an old but beautifully constructed single arch bridge located near the eagle aqueduct in Malaga. It's a short walk from a small beach area, accessible through bamboo tunnels. The bridge is illuminated at night and can be easily reached by car with nearby sand parking. Visitors recommend stopping for a drink at the pleasant square while walking back from the beach and note that it's good for parking motorhomes.
name: Puente del Águila

excerpt: Vegetation backdrops this tranquil, secluded beach in a scenic cove with cliff views.
detail_description: Nestled within the stunning Acantilados de Maro natural reserve, Playa de las Alberquillas is a hidden treasure just ten kilometers from Nerja's bustling center. This secluded beach, framed by lush vegetation and dramatic cliffs, offers an escape into nature’s embrace. With its pristine sands and crystal-clear waters, it’s perfect for those looking to unwind in peace away from crowded urban beaches.
name: Playa de las Alberquillas

detail_description: Playa Playazo is a great place to relax and enjoy the stunning views of Nerja's coastline. There is plenty to do in the nearby city centre, but if you want to get away, then this beach is perfect. With huge sand beaches and some bars and restaurants nearby, there's never been a better time to visit.
name: Playa Vilches

excerpt: A staircase leads to this small, sand & pebble swimming beach surrounded by huge rocks.
detail_description: Carabeo Beach is a hidden gem in the heart of Nerja, known for its exclusivity and privacy. Accessible via a steep staircase from the Carabeo area, this small, secluded beach offers a sense of tranquility and natural beauty. Surrounded by cliffs, it provides a stunning backdrop and shade during hot summer months. With crystal clear waters and no amenities like sun loungers or restaurants, Carabeo Beach is appreciated for its simplicity and unspoiled charm.
name: Carabeo Beach

excerpt: Modern botanical garden featuring typical plants from the local coastal & mountain landscapes.
detail_description: The Botanical Garden Detunda - Cueva de Nerja is a contemporary plant sanctuary showcasing native flora from the nearby coastal and mountain regions. While it may not have perfectly manicured borders due to its focus on conservation, visitors can still appreciate a leisurely stroll through the garden even during the dormant season. The garden offers insights into the unique floral and fauna of the area and is expected to be even more enchanting when spring brings forth vibrant flowers, bushes, and trees in full bloom.
name: Botanical Garden Detunda - Cueva de Nerja
address: Urb. Cueva de Nerja, 3, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: The Art Gallery Alkimia, a venue dedicated to showcasing artistic expressions, offers a diverse assortment of visual creations. This establishment serves as a platform for various artists to present their unique and innovative works. With an extensive range of artwork on display, the gallery enthralls visitors with its captivating exhibits that encompass a wide array of art forms and styles. The collection features paintings, sculptures, installations, and other creative pieces that demonstrate the depth and breadth of artistic talent.
name: Art Gallery Alkimia

detail_description: Plaza De España is a charming square surrounded by cafes and restaurants, offering a beautiful panorama of the nearby mountains. Visitors can admire the work of craftsmen at the market and enjoy a little break in this nice big square. It's also a great place to catch some sun in the park and have a beer or some food while taking in the scenery. With its simple yet appealing design, Plaza De España is definitely worth a visit for anyone exploring the area.
name: Plaza De España
address: Plaza de España, 29780 Nerja, Málaga, Spain

detail_description: Cave rock is a popular location where individuals frequently gather to observe passing tourists. Strangely enough, many have failed to notice the signage located there. This spot serves as an ideal meeting place for people hailing from various parts of the world and offers a unique opportunity to interact with diverse cultures.
name: Cave rock

excerpt: Busy beach backed by palm-topped cliffs, with clear water for snorkeling & many nearby restaurants.
detail_description: Playa El Chucho in Nerja is a beautiful dark sand beach located between Torrecilla Beach and El Playazo Beach. It's perfect for families with its shallow waters, good accessibility, and fewer crowds compared to other beaches in the area. However, it's best to avoid visiting on a busy Sunday during the summer. While there are no bars or restaurants directly on the beach, visitors can enjoy amenities from nearby 4-star hotels like Perla Marina.
name: Playa El Chucho Nerja
address: Mar de Alborán, 18151 Ogíjares, Granada, Spain

detail_description: Calas Torre del Pino, also known as the Pine Coves, is a stunning natural reserve featuring quiet coves nestled among picturesque cliffs. This clothing-optional beach offers crystal-clear waters ideal for snorkeling and diving, making it popular among water sports enthusiasts. Access to the beach can be challenging, and there are no facilities available, so visitors are advised to bring their own supplies.
name: Calas Torre del Pino
